osaka.name: Osaka
funFacts: Osaka is known as Japan's kitchen - it's famous for amazing street food!
Osaka Castle was built over 400 years ago and has survived wars and fires
People in Osaka walk on the right side of escalators, opposite from Tokyo!
The Glico Running Man sign in Dotonbori is one of Japan's most famous landmarks
Osaka has the oldest public bathhouse in Japan, dating back over 1000 years
culturalHighlights: Osakans are known for being friendly and outgoing
Comedy and entertainment culture is huge in Osaka
Street food is meant to be eaten while walking (kuidaore culture)
Merchants and trading have shaped the city's character

observation: Walk through Dotonbori. What colorful signs and smells do you notice?
Watch people enjoying street food. What are they eating?
Compare Osaka Castle to buildings around it. What makes it special?
Listen to the sounds of the city. How is it different from home?
reflection: How do Osakans seem different from people at home?
What would it be like to eat street food here every day?
If you could bring one Osaka tradition home, what would it be?

food: Try takoyaki! Describe the crispy outside and soft inside.
Watch okonomiyaki being made. What ingredients go in?
Visit Kuromon Market. What seafood surprised you most?
animals: Did you visit the Osaka Aquarium? What creature amazed you?
Look for animal mascots on shop signs. Draw your favorite.
What animals did you notice in temple gardens?
art: Find the colorful neon signs of Dotonbori. Which is most creative?
How is Japanese writing (kanji) like art?
Look for traditional art in Osaka Castle. What patterns do you see?
history: What did you learn about the samurai who built Osaka Castle?
Find something ancient and something modern side by side.
How has Osaka changed over hundreds of years?
culture: Why is Osaka called Japan's kitchen?
How is the energy here different from other cities?
What makes Osakans famous for being funny and friendly?

trivia.q: What is Osaka's famous octopus snack called?
What famous castle is in Osaka?
What is Osaka called because of all its great food?

lyon.name: Lyon
funFacts: Lyon is the gastronomic capital of France - it's famous for incredible food!
The city has secret passageways called 'traboules' hidden between buildings
Lyon has one of Europe's best zoos with over 300 species
The Lumi√®re brothers invented cinema here in 1895!
During the Festival of Lights, the whole city glows with amazing light shows
culturalHighlights: Lyon was the silk capital of Europe for centuries
Traditional 'bouchon' restaurants serve hearty local food
Hidden traboules let silk workers move between buildings
Street murals (fresques) decorate walls throughout the city

observation: Find a traboule passageway. What does it feel like walking through?
Look at the murals on buildings. What stories do they tell?
Walk through Old Lyon. How old do the buildings look?
Watch people at a caf√©. What are they eating and drinking?
reflection: Why do you think Lyon became famous for food?
How would you have used the traboules if you were a silk worker?
What makes this city feel different from Paris?

food: Try something at a bouchon restaurant. Describe the flavors.
Visit Les Halles market. What produce looked amazing?
What French pastry was your favorite?
art: Find the famous wall murals. Which one impressed you most?
How did silk weaving become an art form here?
What art did you see at a museum or gallery?
history: Learn about Lyon's silk industry. How did it change the city?
What did you discover about Roman Lyon?
Find something ancient. How has it survived?
animals: Visit Parc de la T√™te d'Or zoo. What was your favorite animal?
What animals did you spot in the parks?
Look for the lion symbols around Lyon!
science: Visit the Lumi√®re Museum. How was cinema invented?
What did you learn at the science museum?
How did silk weaving use early technology?

trivia.q: What secret passageways are hidden in Lyon?
What fabric made Lyon famous?
What was invented in Lyon by the Lumi√®re brothers?

moorea.name: Moorea
funFacts: Moorea means 'yellow lizard' in Tahitian!
The island is shaped like a heart when seen from above
You can feed stingrays and swim with sharks in crystal clear waters
Moorea was formed by a volcano over 2 million years ago
Dolphins and humpback whales visit the island regularly
foods: Poisson cru (raw fish in coconut milk)
culturalHighlights: Polynesian culture values nature and the ocean
Flower crowns and leis are worn for celebrations
Traditional outrigger canoes are still used
Music and dance are central to island life

observation: Look at the water. How many shades of blue can you count?
Watch the fish swimming near shore. What colors do you see?
Climb to a lookout point. Describe the view of the bays.
Notice the tropical flowers. Which ones smell the sweetest?
reflection: How is island life different from life at home?
What does the ocean mean to people who live here?
How would your life change if you lived on this island?

nature: Describe the coral reef you saw. What shapes and colors?
How is this island different from beaches at home?
What did you learn about how the island was formed?
animals: Did you swim with stingrays or sharks? How did it feel?
What tropical fish did you see snorkeling?
Look for dolphins! Describe what you saw.
culture: Learn some Tahitian words. What do they mean?
Watch a traditional dance performance. What story did it tell?
How do islanders use the ocean for food and fun?
food: Try poisson cru! Describe the coconut and fish flavors.
What tropical fruit was your favorite?
How is food different on an island?
science: How was this island created by a volcano?
Learn about coral reefs. Why are they important?
How do ocean currents affect island weather?

trivia.q: What does Moorea mean in Tahitian?
What shape is Moorea when seen from above?
What ocean animals can you swim with in Moorea?

bangkok.name: Bangkok
funFacts: Bangkok's full ceremonial name is the longest city name in the world - 168 letters!
There are over 400 Buddhist temples (wats) in Bangkok
The floating markets sell food and goods from boats!
Tuk-tuks are colorful three-wheeled taxis zooming everywhere
Thai elephants are sacred and were once used by royalty
landmarks: Wat Pho (Temple of the Reclining Buddha)
culturalHighlights: Buddhism is a big part of daily life
The wai greeting (hands together with a bow) shows respect
Street food is everywhere and amazingly delicious
Respect for the royal family is very important

observation: Walk through a temple. What colors and decorations do you see?
Watch the boats on the river. What are people carrying?
Look at the street food stalls. What's cooking?
Notice how people greet each other. What gestures do they use?
reflection: How is Bangkok different from cities at home?
What would it be like to shop at a floating market?
What did you learn about Buddhism from visiting temples?

food: Try pad thai from a street stall. Rate the flavors!
What was the spiciest thing you ate?
Describe mango sticky rice. Was it your favorite dessert?
culture: Learn the wai greeting. When do people use it?
What did you notice about Buddhist monks?
How is Thai culture different from home?
animals: Did you see any elephants? Describe them!
What animals did you spot in temple gardens?
Look for fish in the temple ponds.
art: Describe the gold decorations at the Grand Palace.
How are Thai temples decorated differently from buildings at home?
What patterns do you see repeated in Thai art?
history: What did you learn about Thai kings and queens?
How old are some of the temples you visited?
How has Bangkok changed over time?

trivia.q: What is the most famous noodle dish in Thailand?
What are the colorful three-wheeled taxis called?
What is the Thai gesture of greeting called?

verona.name: Verona
funFacts: Verona is where Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet takes place!
The Arena di Verona is a 2000-year-old Roman amphitheater still used for concerts
Juliet's balcony gets over a million visitors per year
The city has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2000
Verona has the largest Roman arena that is still in use
culturalHighlights: Opera performances in the ancient arena are magical
Caf√© culture - sitting and people-watching is a tradition
Roman and medieval history are everywhere
Shakespeare made this city famous for love stories

observation: Stand in the Arena. Imagine it filled with Romans. What would you hear?
Look at Juliet's balcony. Why do you think people come here?
Walk through Piazza delle Erbe. What's being sold?
Find a Roman ruin. How has it survived 2000 years?
reflection: Why do you think Romeo and Juliet's story is still famous?
How would it feel to watch opera in an ancient arena?
What would your life be like in medieval Verona?

history: What did you learn about Roman Verona?
Compare something Roman to something medieval. What's different?
How has the Arena been used over 2000 years?
art: Find a fresco or painting. What story does it tell?
How is Italian architecture different from home?
Watch an artist painting in the piazza. What are they capturing?
food: Rate your gelato flavors! Which was best?
Try local pasta or risotto. Describe the taste.
What Italian food would you want to cook at home?
culture: Learn some Italian words. Practice them with locals!
How is caf√© culture different from eating at home?
What makes Italian cities feel different from other places?
literature: Read about Romeo and Juliet. What did you learn?
Why did Shakespeare set his play here?
Write your own short love story set in Verona!

trivia.q: Which famous Shakespeare play is set in Verona?
What ancient structure in Verona still hosts concerts?
What Italian frozen treat is Verona famous for?

tokyo.name: Tokyo & Kyoto
funFacts: Tokyo has more Michelin-starred restaurants than any other city in the world!
There are vending machines everywhere in Japan - even for hot ramen!
Train stations play unique melodies when trains arrive
Some traffic lights chirp like birds to help blind people cross
There are cat cafes and owl cafes where you can have drinks with animals
culturalHighlights: Bowing is how people greet each other
You take off your shoes before entering homes
Trains are extremely punctual - even seconds matter!
People are very quiet on public transport

observation: Tokyo's train stations have unique arrival melodies. What sounds did you notice in public spaces?
Look at the vending machines around you. What unusual items did you find for sale?
Japanese streets are very clean. What do you think keeps them so tidy?
Watch people at a crosswalk. How is it different from crosswalks at home?
reflection: How did it feel to bow when greeting someone?
What was the most surprising thing about how people act in Japan?
If you could bring one Japanese tradition home, what would it be?

food: Try using chopsticks for a whole meal. What was the trickiest thing to pick up?
Describe a Japanese food you tried. How is it different from food at home?
Visit a convenience store (konbini). What foods looked interesting?
animals: Did you visit an animal cafe? Describe the experience.
How are pets treated differently in Japan?
Look for animal characters (mascots) everywhere. Draw your favorite one.
art: Find something that shows traditional Japanese art. Describe the patterns you see.
How is Japanese writing (kanji) like art?
What colors are used in Japanese temples and shrines?
transportation: Describe riding the Shinkansen (bullet train). How fast did it feel?
How is the metro system different from trains at home?
Watch how people wait in line for trains. What do you notice?
history: What did you learn about samurai or ninja?
Compare an ancient temple to a modern building in Tokyo.
What symbols or images keep appearing in historic places?

trivia.q: What is Japan's tallest mountain?
What do you call the famous Japanese art of paper folding?
What is the name of Japan's super-fast train?

paris.name: Paris
funFacts: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be temporary and torn down after 20 years!
There are over 470 parks and gardens in Paris
The Louvre is the biggest art museum in the world
French people eat about 30 million baguettes every day
Paris has a beach every summer along the Seine River
culturalHighlights: People often greet with kisses on both cheeks
Lunch is an important meal - shops may close for it
Art and culture are everywhere - on buildings, in parks
Caf√© culture - sitting and watching people is a tradition

observation: French caf√©s are everywhere. Describe a caf√© you visited. What were people doing?
The Eiffel Tower looks different at different times. When did you see it? Describe how it looked.
Walk along the Seine River. What boats, bridges, or activities did you see?
Look at the buildings around you. What makes Parisian architecture special?
reflection: How is the pace of life in Paris different from home?
What would it be like to be an artist living in Paris?
If you could live in any Paris neighborhood, which would you choose and why?

food: Try a French pastry. Describe the taste and texture.
Visit a boulangerie (bakery). What breads and treats did you see?
What French meal was your favorite? How was it served?
art: If you visited the Louvre, which artwork amazed you the most?
How is street art in Paris different from graffiti at home?
Find an artist painting or drawing outside. What are they creating?
history: What did you learn about French kings and queens?
Find something that's over 500 years old. Describe how it looks today.
How has Paris changed over hundreds of years?
architecture: Compare Notre-Dame to a modern building. What's different?
What patterns do you see in Parisian balconies and windows?
Describe the Palace of Versailles. How would you feel living there?

trivia.q: In what year was the Eiffel Tower built?
What famous painting lives in the Louvre?
What river runs through Paris?

london.name: London
funFacts: Big Ben is actually the name of the bell, not the tower!
The London Underground (Tube) is the oldest subway system in the world
Ravens live at the Tower of London - legend says England will fall if they leave!
Red double-decker buses have been in London since 1956
London has been a Roman city, a Viking city, and a Norman city
culturalHighlights: Queueing (standing in line) is taken very seriously!
The Royal Family lives in Buckingham Palace
Double-decker red buses are iconic
Afternoon tea is a British tradition

observation: Watch the Changing of the Guard. Describe what the soldiers wear and do.
Ride a double-decker bus. What can you see from the top?
London has many old and new buildings together. Find an example of each.
Listen to how people talk. What British words or phrases did you hear?
reflection: What would it be like to be royal and live in Buckingham Palace?
How is London similar to and different from other big cities you know?
If you were a guard at the Tower of London, what would your day be like?

history: What did you learn about kings and queens at the Tower of London?
Find something that's over 1000 years old. How has it survived?
How did the Great Fire of London change the city?
animals: Did you see the ravens at the Tower of London? Why are they important?
Visit the Natural History Museum. What creature amazed you most?
What animals did you spot in the Royal Parks?
transportation: Ride the Tube (Underground). How does it compare to subways you know?
Why do you think London has so many famous black taxis?
Find an old and a new way people get around London.
art: Visit a free museum. What artwork or object was your favorite?
Find street performers. What talent did they have?
Look at street art in Shoreditch or Camden. Describe what you see.

trivia.q: What is the river that runs through London?
Where does the King live?
What is the London Underground also called?

orlando.name: Orlando & Disney
funFacts: Walt Disney World is the size of San Francisco!
There are hidden Mickeys all over the Disney parks
Cinderella Castle is 189 feet tall but looks taller due to forced perspective
Orlando gets more visitors each year than any other US city
The parks have underground tunnels called 'utilidors' for cast members
culturalHighlights: Cast members (employees) are always in character
Each park has its own unique theme and story
Parades and fireworks happen daily
Characters walk around for photos and autographs

observation: Find a Hidden Mickey somewhere in the park. Where was it?
Watch how Cast Members interact with guests. What makes them special?
Notice how different lands in the park have different music and smells.
Look at the details in a building facade. What story is it telling?
reflection: If you could design your own theme park ride, what would it be?
What was the most magical moment of your day? Why?
How do the parks make you feel like you're in a different world?

art: Look at how animators brought characters to life. What did you learn?
Notice the artwork throughout the parks. What styles do you see?
Watch a parade. How do costumes and floats create art in motion?
science: What did you learn about space at EPCOT or Kennedy Space Center?
How do roller coasters use physics to create thrills?
What technology makes the rides feel so real?
animals: What did you learn at Animal Kingdom?
Describe an animal you saw on the safari or in exhibits.
How do the parks help protect endangered animals?
music: Listen to the background music in different lands. How does it change?
Describe a show or performance you watched.
What role does music play in making the parks magical?

trivia.q: What year did Walt Disney World open?
What is the big golf-ball shaped building at EPCOT?
What frozen treat is famous at Magic Kingdom?

hawaii.name: Hawaii
funFacts: Hawaii is the only US state made entirely of islands!
Hawaiian has only 13 letters in its alphabet
The islands were formed by underwater volcanoes
Hawaii is home to the only royal palace in the United States
You can ski and surf on the same day in Hawaii!
culturalHighlights: Aloha spirit - treating everyone with love and respect
'Ohana means family - and family is very important
Lei are given as welcomes and celebrations
Hula dancing tells stories through movement

observation: Describe the ocean when you first saw it. What colors? What sounds?
Watch a hula performance. What stories were being told through dance?
Look at a volcanic landscape. How is it different from other mountains?
Notice the plants and flowers around you. Which ones are new to you?
reflection: Hawaiian culture values 'ohana (family). How did you see families spending time together?
What does 'aloha spirit' mean to you after visiting?
How is the pace of life different from home?

nature: Describe the underwater world if you went snorkeling.
What plants or animals did you see that don't live where you're from?
How do volcanoes create new land?
animals: Did you see any sea turtles? Describe the experience.
What birds did you notice that you've never seen before?
Look for fish while snorkeling. Draw your favorites.
science: How were the Hawaiian islands formed?
What did you learn about volcanoes?
How does the ocean affect the weather in Hawaii?
culture: Learn about Hawaiian history. What surprised you?
What Hawaiian words did you learn? What do they mean?
How do native Hawaiian traditions continue today?
food: Try a local dish. How is it different from mainland food?
What tropical fruits did you taste?
Describe your favorite shave ice flavor combination.

trivia.q: How many main islands make up Hawaii?
What is the Hawaiian word for thank you?
What type of geological feature formed the Hawaiian islands?
